text: North Korea has been called out for
breaking UN sanctions they been imposed
to pressure Kim jong-un's government
over its nuclear weapons program but
North Korea has been finding ways to
trade key resources such as coal and oil
we continue to see illegal imports of
additional refined petroleum using
ship-to-ship transfers which are clearly
prohibited under the UN resolution we
must all be accountable for cutting off
North Korea's illegal coal exports which
provide funds that go directly to its
WMD programs so how is North Korea
evading sanctions a lot of this is
happening out at sea and it requires
foreign partners willing to trade
illegally a UN report says there's been
a big increase in transfers of petroleum
products and coal between foreign
tankers and North Korean ships this
enables North Korea to effectively
import these resources restricted under
international sanctions more than 20
North Korean ships have already been
blacklisted by the UN to smuggling fuel
ships can see all our activities by
turning off tracking systems or masking
the vessels true identity North Korea
has also been observed shipping weapons
30,000 rocket-propelled grenades were
found bound for the Suez Canal the ship
sailed under a Cambodian flag but was
crewed by North Koreans the consignment
was falsely labeled for sembly parts for
underwater pumps now the US and others
want to expose the companies involved in
sanctions violations but North Korea
says it can withstand pressure from the
international community
the perception that sanctions can bring
us on our knees is a pipe dream of the
people who are ignorant about us so can
the impact of these sanctions be
measured it's estimated that sanctions
imposed in 2017 cost North Korea 1
billion dollars in lost revenue but the
UN has estimated that North Korea and
two hundred million dollars from illegal
trading for the father's but the actual
amount much higher talks with North
Korea's leader Kim jong-un have opened
up the possibility of lifting sanctions
in the future in return for progress in
reaching a deal to end the country's
nuclear ambitions but for now North
Korea continues to seek ways to survive
under tough international sanctions
[Music]
